text:
Characterization of Phases Formed in the Iron Carbide
Process by X-Ray Diffraction, Mossbauer, X-Ray
Photoelectron Spectroscopy, and Raman Spectroscopy
Analyses
EUNGYEUL PARK, JIANQIANG ZHANG, STUART THOMSON, OLEG OSTROVSKI, and
RUSSELL HOWE
Iron carbide was prepared by iron ore reduction and iron cementation using Ar-H2-CH4 gas mixture
with and without sulfur. Phases formed in the reduction/cementation process were examined by X-
ray diffraction (XRD), Mossbauer, and Raman spectroscopy. The sample surface was also analyzed
by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). XRD and Mossbauer analyses showed that iron oxide
was first reduced to metallic iron, and then, metallic iron was carburized to cementite. Addition of
a small amount of H2S to the reaction gas retarded the cementite formation but made the cementite
more stable. XPS analysis showed that the surface of samples converted to iron carbide using sulfur-
containing gas consisted of mainly Fe3C and a small amount of graphitic carbon. Raman spectra of
a sample produced in the iron carbide process showed the G and D bands, which are characteristic
for carbon-carbon bonds. The intensity ratio of G/D bands depended on the sulfur content in the
reducing/carburizing gas.
I.

B. X-ray Diffraction
Samples were subjected to XRD analysis using a Siemens
D5000, powder diffractometer with nickel-filtered Cu Ka-
radiation. The voltage and current were set at 30 kV and 30
mA. The scanning speed and step size were 0.6 deg/min
and 0.01 deg, respectively.
C. Mossbauer Spectroscopy
The Mossbauer spectra were recorded at room tempera-
ture on a constant acceleration and conventional standard
transmission spectrometer with a 15 mCi 57CoRh source.
The drive velocity scale was calibrated with a 12-mm-thick,
pure a-Fe foil (magnetic hyperfine field Bhf 5 33 T). The
transmission of g-rays through the absorber was detected
using a Krypton-filled proportional detector. The resulting
Mossbauer spectrum was accumulated by a multichannel
analyzer, with 512 channels, and stored in the computer
system for subsequent analysis. All isomer shifts were
quoted relative to the center of the a-Fe calibration spectrum.
The experimental 57Fe Mossbauer spectra were fitted by a
least-squares fitting procedure using the 57Fe Mossbauer
fitting program.
D. X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy
Sample particles were compacted into a thin disk about
1-mm thick under a pressure of 1000 N/cm2 and examined
by a KRATOS XSAM800 instrument. The Mg Ka(1253.6

The free solid carbon was formed as a result of methane
cracking and cementite decomposition. Its content was
obtained as the difference between the total carbon content
in a sample measured by a LECO* CS-244 carbon-sulfur
*LECO is a trademark of LECO Corporation, St. Joseph, MI.
detector and the carbon content in cementite. The free carbon
content in a sample reduced at 835 8C to different extents
is plotted as a function of reaction time in Figure 4. Its
content increased with time.
The XRD patterns of samples reduced/carburized at
925 8C in the gas atmosphere containing sulfur are shown
in Figure 5. The reaction time was 1 hour for all samples.
When the gas atmosphere contained no sulfur, cementite
decomposition at 925 8C was so fast that it was impossible
to convert iron to iron carbide completely. Sulfur stabilized
cementite, and the increase in H2S content in the gas atmos-
phere increased the cementite content in a sample. When
the gas atmosphere contained 0.054 vol pct H2S (this corres-
ponds to an activity of sulphur in iron of 0.28, the activity
of sulfur is assumed to be unity at the Fe/FeS equilibrium
with H2S-H2 gas), the degree of iron conversion to cementite
was close to one. However, addition of sulfur to the reducing/
carburizing gas also retarded cementite formation, so that a
further increase in the H2S content caused a decline in the
cementite content.
Fig. 3—XRD patterns of samples reduced at 835 8C with CH4-H2-Ar gas
(35 vol pct CH4, 55 vol pct H2, and 10 vol pct Ar) at different reduction times.

D. Raman Spectroscopy
No information on the Raman study of iron carbide was
found in literature. Xiang-Xin Bi et al.[15] expected to find
Raman bands between 200 and 600 cm21, but failed to do so.
(a)
The Raman active lattice vibrational modes of an ideal,
iron-carbide, single crystal can be calculated by the correla-
tion method.[16] The space group of cementite is Pnma and
the point group is D16
2h.[17] The lattice vibrational modes of
iron-carbide single crystal, GFe3C are
GFe3C 5 6Au 1 4B1u 1 4B2u 1 4B3u
[2]
All four modes are Raman inactive.
Samples subjected to Raman analysis were the same as
examined by XPS. Raman spectra of a Nucor sample and
sample reduced to different extent at 835 8C, using gas
containing 35 vol pct CH4, 55 vol pct H2, and 10 vol pct
Ar, are shown in Figures 8 and 9, correspondingly. The
(b)

containing 35 vol pct CH4, 55 vol pct H2, 0.054 vol pct H2S,
and 10 vol pct Ar, is presented in Figure 10.

completed in about 15 minutes. In all reduced/carburized
samples, two strong peaks were observed at ,1350 and
,1600 cm21. This doublet is attributed to the so-called D
band and the G band of graphite.[15,20–24] Also, two overtones
and one combination of D and G bands were found at ,2700,
,3200, and ,2950 cm21. The D band occurs at around
1350 cm21 in amorphous sp22 bonded carbon species, such
as pyrolytic graphite, glassy carbon, and carbon powder. In
crystalline graphite, only the G band is observed at around
1600 cm21. Therefore, the intensity of the D band grows
with decreasing fraction of graphite. The Raman data show
that carbon deposition on a sample surface started before
(a)
the completion of the reduction process. However, when the
reduction was completed, the amount of deposited carbon
on a sample surface increased rapidly with the reaction time.
This is agreement with results from carbon analysis (Fig-
ure 4).
In the process of iron oxide reduction and iron cementa-
tion, carbon on the surface of metallic iron, formed as a
result of methane cracking, diffuses to a sample interior
forming iron carbide. Cementite formed on the sample sur-
face acts as a barrier to the carbon diffusion because the
diffusion coefficient of carbon in iron carbide is much
smaller than in pure iron.[25] This causes carbon accumula-
tion on the surface and, eventually, cementite decomposi-
tion.[9]
The proportions of carbon in the amorphous and graphitic
forms can be estimated from the intensity ratio of D to G
bands. The D/G intensity ratio is above one for a Nucor
sample (Figure 8) and a sample reduced by sulfur-containing
gas (Figure 10). This means that carbon in these samples
(b)
predominantly exists in the amorphous phase. Carbon, in a

form of graphite. This supports the Gronebaun and Plusch-

and (b) intermediate and final stages of the reduction showing the peaks

film. The carbon morphology detected by Raman spectros-
copy is in accord with XPS results. However, the origin of
the intense overtone of the D band at 2700 cm21 is not clear.
IV.
CONCLUSIONS
Phases formed in the process of iron carbide formation
by reaction of iron ore with CH4-H2-Ar gas mixtures with
and without sulfur at 750 8C, 835 8C, and 925 8C were
examined by XRD, Mossbauer, XPS, and Raman spectros-
copy. The following phases were identified in samples at
different reduction/cementation stages: iron oxides, metallic
iron, cementite, and free carbon. Results obtained by XRD
and Mossbauer analyses are in a good agreement with one
Fig. 10—Raman spectra of a sample reduced at 925 8C by CH4-H2-Ar gas
(35 vol pct CH4, 55 vol pct H2, and 10 vol pct Ar) containing 0.054 vol
another. Although Mossbauer analysis is more accurate than
pct H2S.
XRD, particular at a low phase content, XRD is quite accept-
able for routine phase analysis.
Surface carbon analyzed by XPS was found to exist in
the form of chemisorbed, graphitic carbon, and iron carbide.
oxide bands. Characteristic peaks of magnetite and wustite
in Raman spectra have very close positions, around 660
